channel.title: Georgios Konstantopoulos / @gakonst
channel.description: Twitter feed for: @gakonst. Generated by nitter.freedit.eu

item.title:
RT by @gakonst: ðŸ¤– New EIP: XXXX
By: - Charlie Noyes -Dan Robinson -Justin Drake -Toni WahrstÃ¤tter
ðŸ”— https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/9241
This EIP proposes delaying the ExecutionPayload's state root reference by one block, so that for each block `n`, the `state_root` in block `n`'s `ExecutionPayload` references the post-state of block `n-1`. This change aims to remove the expensive state root computation from the block-propagation critical path, reducing end-to-end latency for block production and potentially increasing throughput. It simplifies the block production pipeline, accelerates real-time ZK proving, and is a consensus-breaking change requiring a coordinated hard fork.
item.dc:creator: @ethresearchbot
item.description:
ðŸ¤– New EIP: XXXX

By:
- Charlie Noyes
-Dan Robinson
-Justin Drake
-Toni WahrstÃ¤tter

ðŸ”— github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pulâ€¦

This EIP proposes delaying the ExecutionPayload's state root reference by one block, so that for each block `n`, the `state_root` in block `n`'s `ExecutionPayload` references the post-state of block `n-1`. This change aims to remove the expensive state root computation from the block-propagation critical path, reducing end-to-end latency for block production and potentially increasing throughput. It simplifies the block production pipeline, accelerates real-time ZK proving, and is a consensus-breaking change requiring a coordinated hard fork.

item.title:

watch for the spectacular work coming from this group in 2025 â€” itâ€™s going to be a big year as we scale the world computer.

item.title:
RT by @gakonst: After the latest Reth bump, we could 3~4x the throughput limit on 2 test loads without breaking the chain!
Best bump ever and cannot thank the Reth contributors enough (especially in the last month).
Reth is getting more and more stable for high loads ðŸ«¡.
item.dc:creator: @hai_rise
item.description:
After the latest Reth bump, we could 3~4x the throughput limit on 2 test loads without breaking the chain!

Best bump ever and cannot thank the Reth contributors enough (especially in the last month).

Reth is getting more and more stable for high loads ðŸ«¡.

item.title:
RT by @gakonst: Crypto conferences should be hackathons instead of speaker conventions, there are too many talks for the volume of work bearing fruit. Prizes should NOT be monetary
I'm impressed looking back at university hackathon footage, seeing what passionate, curious people built with 0 xp
item.dc:creator: @Rjected
item.description:
Crypto conferences should be hackathons instead of speaker conventions, there are too many talks for the volume of work bearing fruit. Prizes should NOT be monetary

I'm impressed looking back at university hackathon footage, seeing what passionate, curious people built with 0 xp

item.title:
Cross posting my 7702 answers from Warpcast to here because Tony from the Farcaster team asks good questions!
- not necessarily, you can forget the key and just replay the auth sig across chains, delegate to proxy and use the contract to handle upgrades. alternatively can store the privkey in cloud etc encrypted w enclave, nbd imho. - unclear it matters, the ui will give you a preview over x-origin iframe, and your contract will have enough safety checks to ensure you don't get rugged. check secure payment confirmation web api if you really care about doing it non blind. - granted but not deal breaker, your contract can have multiple signers, need to be thoughtful about it but navigable, plus passkeys being pushed top down. - session keys app/account interface is important to get right, see our work in porto for more: https://www.ithaca.xyz/updates/porto, and our WIP session key api which is still evolving: https://github.com/ithacaxyz/porto/tree/next?tab=readme-ov-file#keys - zkemail is fantastic imo and totally underutilized. next up figuring out how to get google's certs reliably on chain as a public good, so we can do jwt verification for oauth. - timelock or otherwise optional. can easily make your account say "if an operation tries to transfer more than X value of such asset, request more auth keys (mfa) and also queue it up for 1mo in the future to ensure user can abort op if hacked from master key"
we have put multiple examples on how to use 7702 and have deployed it on Odyssey, our devnet with Pectra + EOF, see below:
https://github.com/ithacaxyz/odyssey-examples
There's also many examples / demos across Twitter if you search "7702", see eg this one using "anvil --odyssey" which enables the same features Odyssey has but on Anvil (soon Anvil will be running same code as Reth via Reth SDK!)
https://x.com/thegaram33/status/1877410275814445170
There's more going on but this should be a good start for people!
I cannot wait to show the world what full force crypto is, the stack is finally here and we're gonna lead the charge with our years of experience building the best open source tools.
https://warpcast.com/deodad/0x5fca3a10
item.dc:creator: @gakonst
item.description:
Cross posting my 7702 answers from Warpcast to here because Tony from the Farcaster team asks good questions!

- not necessarily, you can forget the key and just replay the auth sig across chains, delegate to proxy and use the contract to handle upgrades. alternatively can store the privkey in cloud etc encrypted w enclave, nbd imho.
- unclear it matters, the ui will give you a preview over x-origin iframe, and your contract will have enough safety checks to ensure you don't get rugged. check secure payment confirmation web api if you really care about doing it non blind.
- granted but not deal breaker, your contract can have multiple signers, need to be thoughtful about it but navigable, plus passkeys being pushed top down.
- session keys app/account interface is important to get right, see our work in porto for more: ithaca.xyz/updates/porto, and our WIP session key api which is still evolving: github.com/ithacaxyz/porto/tâ€¦
- zkemail is fantastic imo and totally underutilized. next up figuring out how to get google's certs reliably on chain as a public good, so we can do jwt verification for oauth.
- timelock or otherwise optional. can easily make your account say "if an operation tries to transfer more than X value of such asset, request more auth keys (mfa) and also queue it up for 1mo in the future to ensure user can abort op if hacked from master key"

we have put multiple examples on how to use 7702 and have deployed it on Odyssey, our devnet with Pectra + EOF, see below:

github.com/ithacaxyz/odysseyâ€¦

There's also many examples / demos across Twitter if you search "7702", see eg this one using "anvil --odyssey" which enables the same features Odyssey has but on Anvil (soon Anvil will be running same code as Reth via Reth SDK!)

x.com/thegaram33/status/1877â€¦

There's more going on but this should be a good start for people!

I cannot wait to show the world what full force crypto is, the stack is finally here and we're gonna lead the charge with our years of experience building the best open source tools.

warpcast.com/deodad/0x5fca3aâ€¦

item.title: RT by @gakonst: Yup, 7702 is necessary for withdraw/pull flows which cannot be implemented into solving flows without risk (user would have to trust solver infra). It also enables solving intents for contracts that don't have a 'address onBehalfOf'-like parameter in their functions.
item.dc:creator: @0xZodomo
item.description: Yup, 7702 is necessary for withdraw/pull flows which cannot be implemented into solving flows without risk (user would have to trust solver infra). It also enables solving intents for contracts that don't have a 'address onBehalfOf'-like parameter in their functions.

item.title:
RT by @gakonst: Excited to announce Porto!
Porto is a developer-first Typescript library that enables auth, crypto payments, and account recovery for your app, wallet or existing toolkit like Wagmi or Privy.
Porto is built on open standards and is released as an Apache/MIT OSS library by @ithacaxyz.
item.dc:creator: @gakonst
item.description:
Excited to announce Porto!

Porto is a developer-first Typescript library that enables auth, crypto payments, and account recovery for your app, wallet or existing toolkit like Wagmi or Privy.

Porto is built on open standards and is released as an Apache/MIT OSS library by @ithacaxyz.

item.title:
RT by @gakonst: Hello EXP-0002, App Sessions.
Fixing UX is the most essential thing in crypto-powered applications.
EXP-0002 is our take on empowering developers with next-generation UX to access cheap and global crypto rails.
No redundant actions or popups, just sessions.
Read on!
item.dc:creator: @ithacaxyz
item.description:
Hello EXP-0002, App Sessions.

Fixing UX is the most essential thing in crypto-powered applications.

EXP-0002 is our take on empowering developers with next-generation UX to access cheap and global crypto rails.

No redundant actions or popups, just sessions.

Read on!

item.title:
RT by @gakonst: Hello EXP-0001.
Today, weâ€™re releasing a deep dive on how Ethereum account delegation with EIP-7702 works, a spec for third parties looking to integrate, and a forkable codebase that you can extend to build next-generation wallets.
And, of course, a demo!
item.dc:creator: @ithacaxyz
item.description:
Hello EXP-0001.

Today, weâ€™re releasing a deep dive on how Ethereum account delegation with EIP-7702 works, a spec for third parties looking to integrate, and a forkable codebase that you can extend to build next-generation wallets.

And, of course, a demo!

item.title:
EIP7702 will 100x EVM chain UX.
We have built the most extensive demos and open source code examples for it so far.
AMA? Happy to help apps, wallets and L2s learn how to integrate.
item.dc:creator: @gakonst
item.description:
EIP7702 will 100x EVM chain UX.

We have built the most extensive demos and open source code examples for it so far.

AMA? Happy to help apps, wallets and L2s learn how to integrate.

item.title: RT by @gakonst: We're open-sourcing Sparse Autoencoders (SAEs) for Llama 3.3 70B and Llama 3.1 8B! These are, to the best of our knowledge, the first open-source SAEs for models at this scale and capability level.
item.dc:creator: @GoodfireAI
item.description: We're open-sourcing Sparse Autoencoders (SAEs) for Llama 3.3 70B and Llama 3.1 8B! These are, to the best of our knowledge, the first open-source SAEs for models at this scale and capability level.

item.title:
RT by @gakonst: 1/ The early net was characterized by competing frameworks w/ hardcoded apps. Then came TCP/IP & the modern web.
Early AI had neural nets with predetermined tasks. Then we got generalized LLMs.
Early ZK was app-specific circuits and rollups. Then came SP1 & Provable Software.
item.dc:creator: @VirtualElena
item.description:
1/ The early net was characterized by competing frameworks w/ hardcoded apps. Then came TCP/IP & the modern web.

Early AI had neural nets with predetermined tasks. Then we got generalized LLMs.

Early ZK was app-specific circuits and rollups. Then came SP1 & Provable Software.

nitter.freedit.eu/SuccinctLabs/status/1877416309434023962#m
